message.content:
<<<api>>>: StringTokenizer.nextToken
<<<code>>>: public void initInventory() throws FileNotFoundException, IOException {
    BufferedReader readInventory=new BufferedReader(new FileReader("E:\\Semester 3\\PointOfSale2\\Inventory.csv"));
    String line=readInventory.readLine();
    StringTokenizer nextItem;
    while(line!=null){
        nextItem=new StringTokenizer(line, ",");
        while(nextItem.hasMoreTokens()){
            String productIDStr = nextItem.nextToken().trim();
            String quantityStr = nextItem.nextToken().trim();
            try {
                int productID=Integer.parseInt(productIDStr); 
                int quantity=Integer.parseInt(quantityStr);
                Inventory inventory=new Inventory(productID, quantity);
                inStock.add(inventory);
            } catch (NumberFormatException e) {
                System.out.println("Invalid number format for productID: " + productIDStr + " or quantity: " + quantityStr);
            }
            line=readInventory.readLine();
        }
    }
    readInventory.close();
}
<<<explanation>>>: The NumberFormatException occurs when you try to parse a String that is not a number into an int. To solve this, you can add a try-catch block around the parsing code to catch the NumberFormatException. In the catch block, you can print an error message that includes the invalid String. This way, you can see which Strings are causing the problem. Also, it's a good practice to trim the String before parsing it to remove any leading or trailing whitespace.
